node.title: The European Central Bank keeps rates steady, despite record inflation.
node.alt: Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank.  In December she said that it was “very unlikely” policymakers would raise interest rates in 2022.
node.description: The E.C.B. held to its policy of easing off support for the economy and tolerating record-high inflation in “the interim,” leaving its interest rate untouched.
node.content: ["The European Central Bank on Thursday kept to its cautious approach in the face of record inflation in the eurozone, but will continue to pull back from its pandemic-era support for the economy.", "A change in policy was not expected when the European Central Bank\u2019s Governing Council met this week for the first time this year, but pressure has been mounting from all sides as prices in Europe continue to rise.", "Traders have been at odds with the central bank\u2019s message that the eurozone economy is not ready for higher interest rates. On Wednesday, before the policy announcement, markets had priced in two 10-basis-point increases in the deposit rate this year. The rate is currently negative 0.5 percent.", "Inflation data released on Wednesday surprised economists, showing that the rate of price rises in January in the 19 countries using the common European currency had reached 5.1 percent compared with a year ago. That was only a slight increase from the 5 percent rate in December, but set yet another record for the eurozone. Analysts had projected that the January rate would fall to 4.4 percent \u2014 still well above the bank\u2019s set target of 2 percent.", "The bank\u2019s Governing Council said on Thursday that it expected the key interest rates will \u201cremain at their present or lower levels\u201d until policymakers see inflation \u201creaching 2 percent well ahead of the end of its projection horizon and durably for the rest of the projection horizon,\u201d adding that it would tolerate higher inflation in the interim.", "The bank also said it remained on track to end its pandemic bond-buying program in March, but maintain support for the economy by continuing another, older bond-buying program.", "Christine Lagarde, the bank\u2019s president, said in December that it was \u201cvery unlikely\u201d policymakers would raise interest rates in 2022, arguing that inflation would ease over the course of the year and settle below the bank\u2019s 2 percent target, warranting the extension of monetary stimulus.", "\u201cInflation is likely to remain elevated for longer than previously expected, but to decline in the course of this year,\u201d she said on Thursday, explaining the council\u2019s decision to maintain the policy set in December.", "She added, \u201cWe will remain attentive to the incoming data\u201d on inflation.", "High energy prices, driven by a geopolitical tensions and the hangover effects of snarled supply chains as economies emerged from the pandemic, have been blamed as the main force pushing prices up. Ms. Lagarde has argued that as demand for energy eases in the spring and deliveries return to normal, prices will come down.", "But other members of the bank\u2019s Governing Council have pointed to other reasons that inflation might remain high longer than expected.", "Earlier this year, Isabel Schnabel, a member of the Executive Board, said the transition to a low carbon economy could require higher fossil fuel prices and rising energy bills and could pose \u201cmeasurable upside risks\u201d to the bank\u2019s inflation projections.", "Luis de Guindos, the bank\u2019s vice president, said in a speech last month that inflation would not be \u201cas transitory as forecast only some months ago.\u201d", "The central bank has insisted that it will not change its interest rates before it stops asset purchases, which inject capital and liquidity into the market. It will update its inflation forecasts again in March.", "\u201cThe E.C.B.\u2019s hopes for a rapid decline in the inflation rate are fading,\u201d Christoph Weil, an economist at Commerzbank, wrote in a note to clients. \u201cThe pressure on the central bank to exit its ultra-expansive monetary policy as early as 2022 is increasing.\u201d", "Earlier on Thursday, the Bank of England raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percent, the second time it has raised rates in the last two meetings, and sad it would also begin to shrink its holdings of government and corporate bonds. In the United States, the Federal Reserve has signaled that it plans to increase interest rates in March."]
